Fields.DialogueText: We're surrounded!
Don't be writing your wills just yet, men! We're not out of this until the final cannon sinks beneath the waves! Isn't that right, Zulu?
I couldn't have put it better myself, Captain!
I could add something about wise men saying to embrace adversity...
The battlefield is no time for Shakespeare, Captain. And it seems my preference for steady and careful tactics would be moot in this situation.
Nothing for it then!
We'll have to blast our way through!
@BATTLE
Phew! What a battle. I'm exhausted.
Shall I pop the kettle on, Captain?
Actually, Zulu - how about I make this pot?

Fields.MenuText: The look on your face...
You don't trust me?

Fields.DialogueText: It isn't that, Captain! It's just...
Forgive me. I may be able to stop my thoughts from spilling to the surface by pressing my lips together, but apparently that causes problems of its own.

Fields.MenuText: I've made tea before, you know?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I know... That's kind of the problem...
Then it's settled! How do you take it?
Honestly, Captain. After all we've been through, you still don't know?
Apologies, my mind is overcrowded with combat strategies and complex schedules.
Two sugars and a splash of milk.
Very well. I'll bring it out to you on the deck in a short while.
Oh, find me below. I'll be making my rounds.
Your rounds?
Usually, before I go to bed, I like to knock once on the doors of each crew member. You know, to let them know that I'll be looking over them.
That doesn't keep them up?
Well, I'm not hammering to be let in. Just a soft tap, to let them know I'm there... to remind me who I'm protecting.
Just something that keeps me sane, you know?
I'm certainly not opposed to that. Maybe you can tuck them in for the night.
Ha! Then I'd never get any sleep...
Here you are, Zulu. As promised, a piping hot cup of tea.
Thank you, Captain. Your concern for me is always appreciated.
Aren't you going to drink it?
I will! I'm just... letting it cool down first.

Fields.MenuText: I remember you once told me "the only good cup of tea is one that burns the inside of your mouth."

Fields.DialogueText: Was that me? You must be thinking of another Belle. Just how many consorts have you been keeping below deck, Captain?
Don't try and change the subject.

Fields.MenuText: Are you smelling it first?

Fields.DialogueText: I just want to make sure you got the balance correct.

Fields.MenuText: That crinkle in your nose is all the explanation I need.

Fields.DialogueText: Blast this emotive face of mine! Luckily, I'm a destroyer. Although I favour tactical espionage on occasion, I prefer doing so at long range... with a couple miles of water between me and my enemy...
Very well. Here goes nothing. Tell the crew that I love them.
If you carry on like this, you really are going to hurt my feelings...
*ALARM*
Morganas!
How convenient...
Do you think I summoned them here to avoid drinking your tea, Captain? Don't be absurd, Belles do not possess such power.
I guess you're right...
Unfortunately, it seems your kind gesture will have grown tepid by the time we finish up.
I'll have to make another round for us then.
Enkulu...
@BATTLE
We're under siege! Quickly, Captain! With me!
@BATTLE
This is going to be an interesting after action report.
We did so as a team, Captain, and now those Morganas won't live to kill another day. You've had enough naval experience to make judgment calls when the enemy surprise us.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe next time you could let THE CAPTAIN make the orders.

Fields.DialogueText: Do not think me insubordinate, Captain. I respect your authority more than anyone aboard this ship.

Fields.MenuText: Where did you learn such combat strategies?

Fields.DialogueText: Watching and learning, mostly. The more experienced Belles have a lot of information to offer. That is how I expect my juniors to learn from me in the future, so I have to set a good example.

Fields.MenuText: Think you've got captain chops?

Fields.DialogueText: On a good day. And on quite a few bad ones.
Procedure is one thing, but no plan survives contact with the enemy.
What do you propose?
A debate. Intuition versus protocol. The material versus the ephemeral.
Agreed - though I don't envy your prospects.
You're that skilled a debater?
I know my limits and my capabilities better than any human. Who knows more than a destroyer about being a destroyer?
Pertinent. I could make an argument for or against that.
Running out of words for "victory," Captain?
Trying to keep our story straight. They got the drop on us, and we deviated pretty heavily from the plan of defence.
What do you say we put that to the test?
And I aced captain school and have the field experience to back it up.
Not against Morganas.
Are we going to debate the terms of the debate too?
... All right. Let's get our assumptions straight first...
*BOOM*
Are you all right, Captain?
Just fine! Let's stay in the fight!
What matters is that we put the Morganas under and got through it without losing anyone.
We did. We also exhausted a fair amount of our ammunition and fuel reserves taking a fight we might better have fled from.
Debate prep, Captain?
After action report. You're certainly giving me ammunition, though.
Just look at this after action report, would you? It's proving compelling reading.
And the blind fire that scored it.

Fields.MenuText: The most important thing is that it's a friendly discussion, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: But you haven't lost if you learn something!

Fields.MenuText: It's a war of words.

Fields.DialogueText: Then watch me prove you wrong as politely as possible!

Fields.MenuText: I'm not a strong debater, so I do hope you'll go easy on me.

Fields.DialogueText: You issued the challenge, Captain! I will come at you with the force of a thousand suns whether we engage in combat training or a mild-mannered game of hopscotch!
It's not a battle, Captain.
Does it feature my direct hit on an enemy magazine?
You can't always trust data and machines, Captain. Especially the evil ones. Sometimes you just know they're lying to you.
You've got your reasons... wherever they come from. Just keep me in the loop.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Isn't your machinery like your senses?

Fields.DialogueText: Not exactly, Captain. I know when it's misbehaving.

Fields.MenuText: Better to have it and not need it.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a different matter entirely!

Fields.MenuText: So you just fight mirages with magical thinking?

Fields.DialogueText: There's nothing magical about instinct!
Look at it this way. Where do you think the Belles were before the Morganas appeared?
There's a rational answer to that. You had to come from somewhere.
Beyond the scope of the debate, but even I can't quite answer that, Captain.
@BATTLE
All I'm saying is that intuition describes things empiricism doesn't.
Which would you use to determine an angle of approach toward an enemy?
Data isn't everything, Captain. Especially when the Morganas can manipulate the parameters and meddle with the machines. Sometimes you have to trust your gut.
Distinction without a difference. It's still data gathering.
Based on what your senses tell you! I don't have to look at the radar to know whether a Morgana is a mirage.
Actually, if you could enlighten me...
... And we're under attack in any event. Table this for now?
Deal. My gut tells me it was just heating up...
*SEVERAL HOURS LATER*
No, Captain! You don't understand! Not everything is measurable by human instruments!
You're drifting into kraken and mermaid territory, Zulu.
We're drifting off the subject altogether.

Fields.MenuText: Moving in mysterious ways, you might say.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't insult my intelligence, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: My throat is starting to hurt.

Fields.DialogueText: Mine too. Shall we take a quick breather?
I don't know if I can stomach much more of this. What say we name you the victor?

Fields.MenuText: I just wish I could understand where you're coming from.

Fields.DialogueText: If I did, do you think it would be called intuition?
You're giving up that easily?
A wise person knows when they are beat. Let's agree to disagree - but, seeing as I am the one throwing in the towel, we can consider this debate a victory for you!
I don't know how I feel about that. Neither of us have budged an inch, and neither has the elephant in the room.
Oh, come on. Don't look a gift whale in the mouth.
And I suppose you are right. The one who sends the invitation should cover the costs. You proposed the debate you conceded, so it's only fair you fund my fee.
*ALARM*
Several Morganas look to be blocking the port's entrance. How about a victory lap, Zulu?
@BATTLE
Ha! You have much to learn about Belles still, but your sense of humour will get you far.
Was there something in particular you were looking for us to buy?
I've been thinking, Captain. It doesn't feel right for me to capitalise on my own beliefs for profit. Are you sure about this?

Fields.MenuText: Wasn't this your idea?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure you were the one insisting on buying me a gift, Captain. Let's say no more about it!

Fields.MenuText: I lost fair and square. Let me treat you.

Fields.DialogueText: Then I'll say no more about it! We'll have dinner and call it even.
*ALARM*
Those Morganas must have called for reinforcements before going down!
Such bloodshed... If only these vile beasts could settle their disputes with words.
I don't think that will be happening anytime soon.
What say we rethink our strategy, Captain? Let's perform maintenance on the ship and come up with a new do-or-die finisher!

Fields.MenuText: Let's test the powers in our possession already against these Morganas!

Fields.DialogueText: Aye-aye, Captain!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Let's just do and leave out the "or die." I have long-term plans that involve being alive.
Lead the way, Zulu.
If you're not, I'm not. But no take-backs.

Fields.DialogueText: I've stuck to my convictions thus far. Let's call it settled.
Everything looks to be in top shape below deck, Zulu.
That's great to hear.

Fields.MenuText: Was there any reason you wanted a check-up?
Have you been feeling under the weather?
How much are you planning to push yourself that we need to make sure you don't burn out?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't fret, Captain, I'll make sure to keep your previous scoldings in mind before doing anything too reckless.
I've never felt better - but, if we plan on pulling off some crazy manoeuvres, I want to make sure I can handle it!
You sound almost like a doctor, Captain!
So what exactly did you have in mind?
So often these Morganas charge headfirst into battle, paying their so-called comrades little to no regard.
They are monsters, after all.
Each battle is much harder for us as, if we sustain even one casualty, the fight cannot be considered won.
Zulu...
You, Captain, the crew, my fellow Belles... I will not allow the lives of my friends to be taken away when a extra moment's planning or a flash of inspiration could have prevented it.
Okay. I approve. Is there a plan, or...?
... I have not decided exactly what actions I will take just yet. Perhaps I will not until the moment comes.
That impassioned speech kind of fell off a little towards the end, but I love the enthusiasm!
*ALARM*
Care to test your hypothesis?
With pleasure!
@BATTLE
But when I do, you can believe that not a Morgana will be left afloat! I'm feeling rather volatile.
I know the sentiment. All too well. You can't...
No. I'm not talking about sentiment. I mean to make advances. I mean to improve our approach. I mean to make more of a difference in a very concrete way.
Captain!
Zulu, how goes the doomsday device?
Less of a device and more a set of interlocking protocols but, either way, I'm at somewhat of an impasse.

Fields.MenuText: You'll get there, don't worry.

Fields.DialogueText: I always do, right?

Fields.MenuText: Do we need such a complex game plan?

Fields.DialogueText: He who makes the first move halves his chance at victory. I know some other destroyers enjoy charging in blindly, but I'm not that kind of Belle.

Fields.MenuText: Writer's block?

Fields.DialogueText: Musings of mass destruction block!
Shall we do something to take your mind off things? A distraction might free up some head space.
Dancing practice?! I'd love to, Captain! Let's adjourn to your room at once!
But--
*ALARM*
No time, Captain! We have company!
@BATTLE
I never knew you had two left feet, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: Can you blame me? The only dancing I've ever done was... well, it's been a while.

Fields.DialogueText: I can tell. These bruises on my feet will last for weeks...

Fields.MenuText: Why are you so interested in dance, anyway?

Fields.DialogueText: As you know, I'm fairly by the books as destroyers go. All that worry and stress for my comrades mounts until I can't hold it back anymore! Instead of lashing out, I prefer to channel it into dance!

Fields.MenuText: Do you have a favorite dancing style?

Fields.DialogueText: Britain perhaps favours slower dances of the ballroom variety, but I can't help but enjoy a faster pace!

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you could teach me some more moves next time?

Fields.DialogueText: I'd be happy to! Just let me invest in some steel-plated boots beforehand!
Does this perhaps illustrate my point, Captain?
Whoa!
As long as you stop putting your feet in my way when I lead!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: It would help if you weren't always trying to lead.

Fields.DialogueText: Tsk. These bruises on my feet will last for weeks.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry. I promise, I'd be doing better if the sea wasn't so damn choppy today.

Fields.DialogueText: There's a rhythm to every dance. But within it...
Concerning?
Cute. Shall we see about these new dance partners?
... Room for improvisation. You may stop spinning now.
Zulu? What is that you've got there?
It's a miniature garden, Captain! One of the crew picked it up for me during our last stop.

Fields.MenuText: Is there a benefit to keeping things smaller scale?

Fields.DialogueText: Not particularly. But it saves a lot of time on the upkeep.

Fields.MenuText: Didn't you already have a small garden like this? I believe I saw it in once in passing.

Fields.DialogueText: This way, there is no risk that my plants will crossbreed. Nothing worse than accidentally growing a sprig of parsbasilmint!

Fields.MenuText: What do you use these herbs for?

Fields.DialogueText: These are much safer than stuffing your body with chemical remedies, Captain!
Of course, for truly dire cases, a physician should be consulted - but for a light scratch, I can patch you up in no time with no problem!
*ALARM*
Quickly, Captain! The herbal therapy lessons will have to wait!
@BATTLE
The right tool for the right job, eh?
My point in a nutshell, Captain.
Heh. You might be on to something.
They're coming along quite nicely, aren't they?
Your sprouts look as if they will blossom very shortly.
Perhaps I should feed them some tea just to ensure they can handle my tastes.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think your interest in tea might be getting a bit... obsessive?

Fields.DialogueText: I can't help liking what I like, Captain. I was raised around the stuff! Tea will always hold a special place in my heart. Or, should I say, stomach.

Fields.MenuText: Do you need to care for these buds so tirelessly?

Fields.DialogueText: How else do you expect them to blossom, Captain? It is thanks to the kind senior Belles that I have not been sunk as of yet.
Had they left me to my own devices, not imparting their words of wisdom, I don't know where I would be today!

Fields.MenuText: Do you mind if I water this one here?

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
Zulu?
First, you insist on making the tea, now you want to overhydrate the herbs. Do you take pleasure in watching me squirm, Captain?
I just wanted to help out is all.
Apologies. It's just... I run a very tight ship when it comes to my hobbies. No pun intended...
If only we could grow some kind of Morgana repellent!
No need, Captain! Your scarecrow is right here!
@BATTLE
Zulu! Please, could we borrow you for a moment?
What seems to be the--
Never have I seen someone so blind!
I'm the one who should be saying that!
Silence, men! That's an order!
Oh, my, you're all riled up.
It seems we have a minor dispute on our hands.
I can see that, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Would you mind mediating?

Fields.DialogueText: I'd be happy to give an unbiased opinion if you think it would help.

Fields.MenuText: Do you have any idea what this might be about?

Fields.DialogueText: I haven't heard of any arguments in some time now. I was under the assumption people were relatively comfortable about this vessel.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps some corporal punishment is in order?

Fields.DialogueText: Should we resort to such methods, we are no better than the Morganas. Real men... and Belles... settle their disputes with words.
*ALARM*
Damn it all, can my ears get a moment's peace?
Simmer down, Captain. We'll take care of these Morganas and move to your quarters to hear each side of the story.
@BATTLE
Proceed.
I keep a lucky necklace with me at all times. This morning I woke to find it missing. Where should I spy it later in the day? Around his neck!
Nonsense! I've had this necklace since we first set sail!
Thief!
Gentlemen! Please!

Fields.MenuText: What do you think, Zulu?

Fields.DialogueText: It certainly is a tough one. I would not like to think anyone aboard this ship a thief, but it is evidence enough that someone is a liar.

Fields.MenuText: Can you draw on any past experiences, Zulu?

Fields.DialogueText: None, I'm afraid. I'll have to use my cunning to find the culprit.

Fields.MenuText: What would King Solomon say?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm...
*ALARM*
Leave Zulu to think, men. Attend to the Morganas and return here at once for the verdict!
Aye-aye, Captain!
Aye-aye, Captain!
@BATTLE
Now then, the Captain and I have decided that it is better to move past this incident for the sake of crew morale. None of us want to think a thief or a liar is among us.
So we're writing this off as honest confusion and de-escalating all around.
We will throw the necklace overboard and I personally will reimburse the both of you for it.

Fields.MenuText: I can help with that.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain! That's very much appreciated.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. The crew and their happiness mean more to me than any sum of money.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, Zulu will handle it!

Fields.DialogueText: Don't wear your stinginess quite so overtly, Captain. It's unbecoming.
I think that's fair.
Something the matter? Speak up, man!
*ALARM*
Forge your sentence on the battlefield! I will not tolerate any more time wasted!
@BATTLE
Come now, speak up!
Please, Captain... Reimburse him double the amount, but let the necklace stay above water. It was a gift from my beloved before she lost her life.
I think we have our answer.

Fields.MenuText: Did you plan this all along?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course! It is a very popular mediation trick!

Fields.MenuText: Very impressive.

Fields.DialogueText: Do not praise me, Captain. It's really all down to King Solomon!

Fields.MenuText: Any man who would lie about such things is more Morgana than human.

Fields.DialogueText: I agree. It must belong to the widower.
Anything to say for yourself, sailor?
I'm sorry, Captain! My family back home... they're starving... I've fallen behind on payments and... and...
Save your tears, man - they'll be washed up by the unforgiving sea. Here.
Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Half of my monthly pay. Spend it wisely. Don't think of it as a reward for your actions but more of a purchasing of your loyalty.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain! Oh, god, thank you!
Now, both of you get back to work!
Yes, Captain!
Captain?

Fields.MenuText: It's a loan. A loan which you will repay as soon as you're able if you don't want to swim home.
I'm paying you to shut up and get out of my office. I suggest you take it.

Fields.DialogueText: All right, maybe you do have a point.
One of them said something, the other said something else. You trusted on the truth to come out with that bluff. Intuition.
I wouldn't call it that, Captain. Everyone has something they can't replace. All I needed to do was threaten it. What's more material than that?
Proving my point, then, eh? Looks like we're even.
Take your wins where you can get them, Captain - though I don't mind trading now and again.
Thanks to your generosity, Captain, we'll have to be a little tighter with our expenditure.

Fields.MenuText: It can't be helped. The crew, as you know, are the backbone of any naval vessel.

Fields.DialogueText: You're preaching to the choir, Captain! I know it was a necessary expense... but how do you still feel about upgrading our firepower?
You know better than I do how much pulling those strings can take.
You're right. Let's hold off on buying anything for now.
As you wish.
Several Morganas look to be blocking our exit. Let's take them out before they reach the shore.
Yes, Captain!
@BATTLE
We did have a line on a British six-incher, fairly recent make. I'd have to pull a few strings...

Fields.MenuText: I don't know what you're complaining about. It was *my* money.

Fields.DialogueText: But isn't it really *our* money, in the long run?
... No. Not at all.
Moving on, how would you feel about upgrading our firepower?

Fields.MenuText: Please don't remind me.

Fields.DialogueText: But it's so satisfying.
Zulu? Is there any reason you're patting yourself down like that?
Apologies, Captain, it's a habit I picked up from the other crew members.

Fields.MenuText: You're a little supersitious, aren't you, Zulu?

Fields.DialogueText: It helps keep me focused if I can attribute the act of doing something with a small ritual. All Brits are a little superstitious, but this has nothing to do with supernatural bad luck.

Fields.MenuText: Did you always carry a fondness for rituals?

Fields.DialogueText: For as long as I can remember, at least.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not very ritualistic myself.

Fields.DialogueText: That's okay, Captain! You're free to join in with mine!
So, what is this patting ritual supposed to be?
The men perform it before they head out on the town. You touch your face, your waist, your pocket and your wrist.
Is that so?
There was a cute rhyme with it as well but I can't remember it all! "Spectacles, something, wallet, and watch." I can't think of another word that rhymes with spectacles, though...
*ALARM*
We all have our rituals, I suppose. Just... maybe don't make a habit of that one.
@BATTLE
We're taking fire! To your positions!
@BATTLE
Phew! What a battle. I hope your stategy is near completion, Zulu.
You can't rush creativity, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: We must find a way to end this war quickly.

Fields.DialogueText: Seconded. However, an unprepared move could spell disaster for us all.

Fields.MenuText: Would you be willing to have a discourse with the Morganas if they had the ability?

Fields.DialogueText: I believe the acts committed by those monsters no longer allow for such pleasantries. I am still a destroyer and I will uphold that title until my dying breath.

Fields.MenuText: After the war, what will you do?

Fields.DialogueText: You know... I've been so invested in the lives of the crew, I've had very little time to think about it. Perhaps you could take me somewhere nice, Captain!
*ALARM*
We'll have to rely on good ol' fashioned brute force for this fight, then.
Now that's a dance I know by heart!
@BATTLE
Zulu, there you are!
Captain... My apologies. I know I've been scarce today.
No worries. Making your rounds again?
A double dose. I thought... well, it seemed necessary.
Keeping extra vigilant?
You could say that. When I knocked on the very first door, this happened.
A splinter?
The worst kind, Captain. It's a bad omen. Something is in the water and my strategy can only get us so far.

Fields.MenuText: Don't push yourself, Zulu.

Fields.DialogueText: Your kind words, although pleasing, will not save us from a watery grave...

Fields.MenuText: I'm always here if you need me to help.

Fields.DialogueText: That's what friends are for, right?

Fields.MenuText: I'm worried about you.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry, Captain. I won't be collapsing again anytime soon.
*ALARM*
It's time... Brace yourself, Captain. I fear this battle will be only one of many.
@BATTLE
What the hell kind of sense--
From a metal door, no less.
Omens? Zulu, I--
You've seen things that weren't there since this war began, Captain. Heard things that weren't said.
When I get a splinter from my own structure... well, I know something's wrong. I have to be ready for anything, natural or otherwise.
You were right, Zulu - that looked like a scouting party.
We're being tailed, it seems. We should make haste before they catch up to us.
Yes, most definitely. There's a port up ahead. We can restock there and then... your garden.
Hm? Oh, yes, I left it out here to get some sunlight. I guess the cannon fire proved too much for the poor sprouts.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry, Zulu.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, please! Do not look so upset! No lives were lost and I can plant more seeds. I know my earlier metaphors were vivid, but you don't need to go so far.

Fields.MenuText: I'll buy you a new garden.

Fields.DialogueText: And a house along with it, please!

Fields.MenuText: Better the plants than us.

Fields.DialogueText: Lucky for us, these sprouts had yet to find their sea legs! Real sailors won't go down so easily.
Several Morganas are blocking the entrance to the port. Let's see if we can deal with them quietly so as not to draw more unwanted attention.
@BATTLE
That should be enough supplies for the upcoming battle.
Agreed. Unless we want to bolster our reserves - there's a naval academy in port we might be able to raid for personnel.
It would be nice to have some extra hands on deck... I'll leave the decision up to you.

Fields.MenuText: Consider it done. I'll make the trip over while you load up.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: On second thought, I'm sure our teamwork will prove sufficient.

Fields.DialogueText: It hasn't failed us yet!
Try not to look so anxious, Zulu. I know your rituals are important to you, but that splinter could just have been coincidence.
It's only coincidence if you don't read into it.
Perhaps... perhaps I should be doing more of that.
Reading into things?
Not reading into things.
Again with the back-and-forth.
Hmm. They're catching up, Captain. Let's take this fight in more open waters.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: ... Nah. Let's let them bake before we take them out of the oven.

Fields.DialogueText: Vaguely unappetising metaphor, Captain.
That is some fleet, huh?
I'm putting a lot of faith in you, Zulu. I trust you'll always keep the fate of the crew at the front of your mind.
There never goes a second where that is not the case, Captain.
Would you care to explain your strategy yet?
If you'll remember, Captain, we previously masked ourselves in smoke to act as camouflage.
It proved relatively effective, if I recall.
Indeed it did - but using such a strategy may prove risky if we burn out and come to a halt.
Where are you going with this, Zulu?
We are only ever at risk when taking on fleets as large as these. That is why we needed to mask ourselves to pick off opponents one by one.
Yes?
However, we only need the cover of smoke to collect our thoughts when positioning and firing.
I'm still with you... barely...
And in any event, the strategy only works in tandem with spotters and proper weather conditions.

Fields.MenuText: It's almost more useful for the Morganas than for us, under certain circumstances.

Fields.DialogueText: My thoughts precisely!

Fields.MenuText: So, what you're saying is...?

Fields.DialogueText: We turn it around on them.

Fields.MenuText: You're trying to talk yourself into something, but I don't know what.

Fields.DialogueText: The first person you have to convince of a hard choice is yourself.
Load smoke shells, Captain. We're turning it around on the Morganas. There are too many to just hide ourselves.
... That's it?
You were expecting something more elaborate?
@BATTLE
The way you've built it up, kind of.
Maybe that was the problem to begin with.
You're talking in riddles again.
Here they come. Let's say I'm working out the terms of the debate.
How are you holding up, Zulu?
We're unharmed thus far, but the smoke is running low!
@BATTLE
I think that's the last of them...

Fields.MenuText: I can't believe we made it out of that one alive.

Fields.DialogueText: If I'm being perfectly honest, I was only 99% sure that it would work...

Fields.MenuText: You've saved us again, Zulu.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't need to hear it, Captain. All I need to hear are the beating hearts of each crew member.

Fields.MenuText: We're going to need more smoke for next time.

Fields.DialogueText: We don't need to blot out the sky, Captain. Just cover their eyes for a bit.
Let's rest up at that town in the distance. We have a long road ahead.
I was afraid of that. We can't keep them guessing forever. I think we'll have to--
Fight a retreat.
I-- yes, exactly. Zulu--
There are always more Morganas. We've all got something we can't replace, Captain. It's time we owned up to that.
Right. Let's give the command to withdraw guns blazing.
Let's. We've earned it.
Captain? You wanted to see me? You're back from shopping already?
We'll be heading out again soon, but I had to pick something up first.
What is... A miniature garden?
Your last one was destroyed in battle, correct? I hope this is a fitting replacement.
Captain...

Fields.MenuText: I've already planted two sprigs for you to care for.

Fields.DialogueText: Have you watered them?! Have they been properly fertilized? What kind of songs have you been singing to them?!

Fields.MenuText: Consider it a gift.

Fields.DialogueText: You shouldn't have, Captain...

Fields.MenuText: I didn't know what sort of herbs you favor, so I got a little of everything.

Fields.DialogueText: Haha! Of course, you're right again, Captain!
*ALARM*
Blasted Morganas. No time to load the smoke this time, Zulu.
@BATTLE
Captain... keep it.
Ideally, they don't take anything.
... Captain. Will you join me tonight?
Although, perhaps you'll allow ME to put the kettle on instead...
*Sigh* Never change, Zulu. Never change.
On your rounds, you mean?
It clears my mind, Captain. We all have rituals, practices, strategies... anything to keep us grounded.
I'll drink to that. Tea?
It's something they don't teach at the naval academy, and they probably shouldn't. But it's got its place nonetheless.
Tea.
No need. Let's take them out!
Another day, another port to defend.
I bet that new garden would be just the thing to relax with.
Glad for the opportunity as always, but what a fight that was...
You don't want it?
I hate to lose things, but... well, they're just things. There's worse the Morganas could have taken from us.
Remember the necklace, Captain?
I meant it when I said I'd throw it overboard. Whoever was right... whoever was wrong... if I'd done that, at least the argument would have been moot.
As judgment calls go, that's not a tough one.
No. No, it's not. But it's good practice.
